conversation.user: Do the marks in Japanese characters count as glyphs?

expected_response: While separate marks in Japanese characters do not generally count as glyphs on their own because they have no independent meaning, certain additional marks that serve as diacritics can be considered glyphs since they differentiate distinct characters.
returned_response:

In summary, while most separate marks in Japanese characters do not count as glyphs on their own, certain additional marks that serve as diacritics can be considered glyphs.

In most languages written in any variety of the [Latin alphabet](/wiki/Latin_alphabet "Latin alphabet") except English, the use of [diacritics](/wiki/Diacritic "Diacritic") to signify a sound mutation is common. For example, the grapheme ⟨à⟩ requires two glyphs: the basic a and the [grave accent](/wiki/Grave_accent "Grave accent") `. In general, a diacritic is regarded as a glyph,[[2]](#cite_note-Whistler_et_al-3) even if it is contiguous with the rest of the character like a [cedilla](/wiki/Cedilla "Cedilla") in [French](/wiki/French_language "French language"), [Catalan](/wiki/Catalan_language "Catalan language") or [Portuguese](/wiki/Portuguese_language "Portuguese language"), the [ogonek](/wiki/Ogonek "Ogonek") in several languages, or the stroke on a Polish "[Ł](/wiki/%C5%81 "Ł")". Although these marks originally had no independent meaning, they have since acquired meaning in the field of mathematics and computing, for instance.

Conversely, in the languages of Western Europe, the [dot](/wiki/Tittle "Tittle") on a lower-case ⟨i⟩ is not a glyph in itself because it does not convey any distinction, and an ⟨ı⟩ in which the dot has been accidentally omitted is still likely to be recognized correctly. However, in [Turkish](/wiki/Turkish_language "Turkish language") and adjacent languages, this dot is a glyph because that language has two distinct versions of the letter _i_, [with](/wiki/%C4%B0 "İ") and [without a dot](/wiki/Dotless_I "Dotless I"). 

In Japanese [syllabaries](/wiki/Syllabary "Syllabary"), some of the characters are made up of more than one separate mark, but in general these separate marks are not glyphs because they have no meaning by themselves. However, in some cases, additional marks fulfil the role of [diacritics](/wiki/Diacritic "Diacritic"), to differentiate distinct characters. Such additional marks constitute glyphs. 

Some characters such as "[æ](/wiki/%C3%86 "Æ")" in [Icelandic](/wiki/Icelandic_language "Icelandic language") and the "[ß](/wiki/%C3%9F "ß")" in [German](/wiki/German_language "German language") may be regarded as glyphs. They were originally typographic [ligatures](/wiki/Ligature_(writing) "Ligature (writing)"), but over time have become characters in their own right; these languages treat them as unique letters. However, a ligature such as "fi", that is treated in some typefaces as a single unit, is arguably not a glyph as this is just a design choice of that typeface, essentially an [allographic](/wiki/Allograph "Allograph") feature, and includes more than one [grapheme](/wiki/Grapheme "Grapheme").[[2]](#cite_note-Whistler_et_al-3) In normal handwriting, even long words are often written "joined up", without the pen leaving the paper, and the form of each written letter will often vary depending on which letters precede and follow it, but that does not make the whole word into a single glyph.

In [typography](/wiki/Typography "Typography"), a glyph is "the specific shape, design, or representation of a character".[[1]](#cite_note-1) It is a particular graphical representation, in a particular [typeface](/wiki/Typeface "Typeface"), of an element of written language. A [grapheme](/wiki/Grapheme "Grapheme"), or part of a grapheme (such as a [diacritic](/wiki/Diacritic "Diacritic")), or sometimes several graphemes in combination (a composed glyph)[[a]](#cite_note-2) can be represented by a glyph.

<headings>Glyphs, graphemes and characters</headings>
Older models of [typewriters](/wiki/Typewriter "Typewriter") required the use of multiple glyphs to depict a single character, as an overstruck [apostrophe](/wiki/Apostrophe "Apostrophe") and [period](/wiki/Full_stop "Full stop") to create an [exclamation mark](/wiki/Exclamation_mark "Exclamation mark"). If there is more than one allograph of a unit of writing, and the choice between them depends on context or on the preference of the author, they now have to be treated as separate glyphs, because mechanical arrangements have to be available to differentiate between them and to print whichever of them is required. 

In [computing](/wiki/Computing "Computing") as well as typography, the term "[character](/wiki/Character_(computing) "Character (computing)")" refers to a grapheme or grapheme-like unit of text, as found in [natural language](/wiki/Natural_language "Natural language") [writing systems](/wiki/Writing_system "Writing system") (_scripts_). In typography and computing, the range of graphemes is broader than in a written language in other ways too: a typeface often has to cope with a range of different languages each of which contribute their own graphemes, and it may also be required to print non-linguistic symbols such as [dingbats](/wiki/Dingbat "Dingbat"). The range of glyphs required increases correspondingly. In summary, in typography and computing, a glyph is a [graphical](/wiki/Graphics "Graphics") unit.[[2]](#cite_note-Whistler_et_al-3)

In [computing](/wiki/Computing "Computing") as well as typography, the term "[character](/wiki/Character_(computing) "Character (computing)")" refers to a grapheme or grapheme-like unit of text, as found in [natural language](/wiki/Natural_language "Natural language") [writing systems](/wiki/Writing_system "Writing system") (_scripts_). In typography and computing, the range of graphemes is broader than in a written language in other ways too: a typeface often has to cope with a range of different languages each of which contribute their own graphemes, and it may also be required to print non-linguistic symbols such as [dingbats](/wiki/Dingbat "Dingbat"). The range of glyphs required increases correspondingly. In summary, in typography and computing, a glyph is a [graphical](/wiki/Graphics "Graphics") unit.[[2]](#cite_note-Whistler_et_al-3)

In most languages written in any variety of the [Latin alphabet](/wiki/Latin_alphabet "Latin alphabet") except English, the use of [diacritics](/wiki/Diacritic "Diacritic") to signify a sound mutation is common. For example, the grapheme ⟨à⟩ requires two glyphs: the basic a and the [grave accent](/wiki/Grave_accent "Grave accent") `. In general, a diacritic is regarded as a glyph,[[2]](#cite_note-Whistler_et_al-3) even if it is contiguous with the rest of the character like a [cedilla](/wiki/Cedilla "Cedilla") in [French](/wiki/French_language "French language"), [Catalan](/wiki/Catalan_language "Catalan language") or [Portuguese](/wiki/Portuguese_language "Portuguese language"), the [ogonek](/wiki/Ogonek "Ogonek") in several languages, or the stroke on a Polish "[Ł](/wiki/%C5%81 "Ł")". Although these marks originally had no independent meaning, they have since acquired meaning in the field of mathematics and computing, for instance.

Conversely, in the languages of Western Europe, the [dot](/wiki/Tittle "Tittle") on a lower-case ⟨i⟩ is not a glyph in itself because it does not convey any distinction, and an ⟨ı⟩ in which the dot has been accidentally omitted is still likely to be recognized correctly. However, in [Turkish](/wiki/Turkish_language "Turkish language") and adjacent languages, this dot is a glyph because that language has two distinct versions of the letter _i_, [with](/wiki/%C4%B0 "İ") and [without a dot](/wiki/Dotless_I "Dotless I"). 

In Japanese [syllabaries](/wiki/Syllabary "Syllabary"), some of the characters are made up of more than one separate mark, but in general these separate marks are not glyphs because they have no meaning by themselves. However, in some cases, additional marks fulfil the role of [diacritics](/wiki/Diacritic "Diacritic"), to differentiate distinct characters. Such additional marks constitute glyphs. 

Some characters such as "[æ](/wiki/%C3%86 "Æ")" in [Icelandic](/wiki/Icelandic_language "Icelandic language") and the "[ß](/wiki/%C3%9F "ß")" in [German](/wiki/German_language "German language") may be regarded as glyphs. They were originally typographic [ligatures](/wiki/Ligature_(writing) "Ligature (writing)"), but over time have become characters in their own right; these languages treat them as unique letters. However, a ligature such as "fi", that is treated in some typefaces as a single unit, is arguably not a glyph as this is just a design choice of that typeface, essentially an [allographic](/wiki/Allograph "Allograph") feature, and includes more than one [grapheme](/wiki/Grapheme "Grapheme").[[2]](#cite_note-Whistler_et_al-3) In normal handwriting, even long words are often written "joined up", without the pen leaving the paper, and the form of each written letter will often vary depending on which letters precede and follow it, but that does not make the whole word into a single glyph.

Look up ___[glyph](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/glyph "wiktionary:glyph")___ in Wiktionary, the free dictionary.__This page uses notation for orthographic or other linguistic analysis.__ For the meaning of how `⟨ ⟩`, `| |`, `/ /`, and `[ ]` are used here, see [this page](/wiki/International_Phonetic_Alphabet#Brackets_and_transcription_delimiters "International Phonetic Alphabet").A __glyph__ ([/ɡlɪf/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") [_GLIF_](/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key "Help:Pronunciation respelling key")) is any kind of purposeful mark. In [typography](/wiki/Typography "Typography"), a glyph is "the specific shape, design, or representation of a character".[[1]](#cite_note-1) It is a particular graphical representation, in a particular [typeface](/wiki/Typeface "Typeface"), of an element of written language. A [grapheme](/wiki/Grapheme "Grapheme"), or part of a grapheme (such as a [diacritic](/wiki/Diacritic "Diacritic")), or sometimes several graphemes in combination (a composed glyph)[[a]](#cite_note-2) can be represented by a glyph.

1. At the request of an employee, leave without pay for a period of up to one (1) year shall be granted to an employee whose spouse is permanently relocated and up to five (5) years to an employee whose spouse is temporarily relocated.
2. Leave without pay granted under this clause shall be deducted from the calculation of continuous employment for the purpose of calculating severance pay and service for the purpose of calculating vacation leave for the employee involved, except where the period of such leave is less than three (3) months. Time spent on such leave which is for a period of more than three (3) months shall not be counted for pay increment purposes.

__21.13 Leave with pay for family-related responsibilities__

1. For the purpose of this clause, family is defined as per Article 2 and, in addition, children of spouse, parents of a spouse or common-law partner or any relative for whom the employee has a duty of care, irrespective of whether they reside with the employee.
2. The total leave with pay which may be granted under this clause shall not exceed thirty-seven decimal five (37.5) hours in a fiscal year.
3. The Employer shall grant leave with pay under the following circumstances:
	1. to take a family member for medical or dental appointments, or for appointments with school authorities or adoption agencies, if the supervisor was notified of the appointment as far in advance as possible;
	2. to provide for the immediate and temporary care of a sick member of the employee’s family and to provide an employee with time to make alternate care arrangements where the illness is of a longer duration;
	3. to provide for the immediate and temporary care of an elderly member of the employee’s family;
	4. for needs directly related to the birth or to the adoption of the employee’s child
	5. to attend school functions, if the supervisor was notified of the functions as far in advance as possible;
	6. to provide for the employee’s child in the case of an unforeseeable closure of the school or daycare facility;\*\*

	7. to visit a family member who, due to an incurable terminal illness, is nearing the end of their life;\*\*

	8. fifteen (15) hours of the thirty-seven decimal five (37.5) hours stipulated in paragraph 21.13(b) above may be used to attend an appointment with a legal or paralegal representative for non-employment-related matters, or with a financial or other professional representative, if the supervisor was notified of the appointment as far in advance as possible.
4. Where, in respect of any period of compensatory leave, an employee is granted leave with pay for illness in the family under paragraph 21.13(c) above, on production of a medical certificate, the period of compensatory leave so displaced shall either be added to the compensatory leave period, if requested by the employee and approved by the Employer, or reinstated for use at a later date.

__21.14 Court attendance leave__

1. to serve on a jury or to be available for jury selection;

Various glyphs representing lower case letter "[a](/wiki/A "A")" in various fonts and as single and double story; they are [allographs](/wiki/Allograph "Allograph") of the [grapheme](/wiki/Grapheme "Grapheme") ⟨a⟩

Look up ___[glyph](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/glyph "wiktionary:glyph")___ in Wiktionary, the free dictionary.__This page uses notation for orthographic or other linguistic analysis.__ For the meaning of how `⟨ ⟩`, `| |`, `/ /`, and `[ ]` are used here, see [this page](/wiki/International_Phonetic_Alphabet#Brackets_and_transcription_delimiters "International Phonetic Alphabet").A __glyph__ ([/ɡlɪf/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") [_GLIF_](/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key "Help:Pronunciation respelling key")) is any kind of purposeful mark. In [typography](/wiki/Typography "Typography"), a glyph is "the specific shape, design, or representation of a character".[[1]](#cite_note-1) It is a particular graphical representation, in a particular [typeface](/wiki/Typeface "Typeface"), of an element of written language. A [grapheme](/wiki/Grapheme "Grapheme"), or part of a grapheme (such as a [diacritic](/wiki/Diacritic "Diacritic")), or sometimes several graphemes in combination (a composed glyph)[[a]](#cite_note-2) can be represented by a glyph.
